oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Shelby Lynne Interview (featuring Bob Montgomery) - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Shelby Lynn (performer) and Bob Montgomery (producer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Shelby Lynne; Bob Montgomery; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Biff Collie, Bob Montgomery and Shelby Lynne discuss Lynne's vast musical knowledge and the changing audio formats -- (00:47) Collie reveals he was a member of a band named the Three B's; the members were Collie, William Stubblefield, and Hugh Lee Bosman -- (01:10) Lynne discusses her desire to continue the Mills Brothers legacy and Collie reveals from recalling a line spoken to him by Bob Tubert -- (02:28) Montgomery reflects on the structure of the music industry forcing artists to create inorganic music -- (04:53) Montgomery discusses the first time Lynne was offered a deal, under a development contract, from Billy Sherrill -- (05:31) Lynne reveals how she had trusted Montgomery even though they had only recently met and Montgomery reveals what he knows of development contracts -- (07:40) Lynne discusses the non-issue associated with money -- (08:08) Lynne radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (08:16) Lynne radio spot with the Biffer -- (08:21) Lynne, disc jockey, radio spot for Biff Collie and the Music City Album Review -- (08:31) Lynne radio spot for her audiobiography and the Music City Album Review -- (08:44) Lynne, thirty minute, radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (08:52) Lynne, hour, radio spot for the Music City Album Review -- (09:01) Lynne thanking radio spot -- (09:07) Lynne radio spot for her audiobiography and the Music City Album Review -- (09:17) Lynne listening radio spot -- (09:19) Lynne winning radio spot -- (09:26) Collie directs Lynne to say "Oh really?" -- (09:29) Collie directs Lynne to say "Oh yeah?" -- (09:34) Collie directs Lynne to say "Wonderful" -- (09:36) Lynne says she hates the word wonderful -- (09:43) Collie directs Lynne to say "Now you're going" -- (09:46) Collie directs Lynne to say "You bet" -- (09:48) Collie directs Lynne to say "Would you repeat that please?" -- (09:51) Collie directs Lynne to say "Yes sir" -- (09:54) Collie directs Lynne to say "Sure" -- (09:57) Collie directs Lynne to say "That's what I like to hear" -- (10:01) Collie directs Lynne to say "That's nice" -- (10:03) Collie asks Lynne to perform her own catch-phrases and Montgomery, Lynne and Collie discuss Collie's editing process -- (11:20) Collie and Lynne discuss Lynne's album title Sunrise -- (11:49) Collie addresses Montgomery's value as a conversation driver -- (12:24) Collie and Lynne discuss how Lynne had got a contract with CBS through an appearance on Nashville Now -- (13:21) 'The Hurtin' Side' and its writers, Mike Reid and Michael Bourke, are discussed as "career boosters" -- (14:20) Montgomery discusses the hits he produced, and Montgomery reflects on understanding Lynne's potential; Montgomery compares Lynne to Red Foley -- (16:05) Collie introduces 'Little Bits and Pieces' and Lynne reflects on her luck of having song writers such as Billy Sherrill -- (16:52) Collie and Lynne reflect on the duration of the recording process and Lynne tells of Sherrill's temper associated with him having to wait for new songs -- (18:02) Montgomery tells of how 'Thinking About You Again' came off the streets of Nashville and Lynne reflects on a night working at Blue Bird; while at the Blue Bird, Lynne unknowingly met Smith -- (19:01) Montgomery and Lynne express their appreciation for Smith's help at the Blue Bird and assert their recording of Smith had been purely based on merit -- (19:56) Collie and Lynne discuss how Shelby is a man's name and Lynne and Montgomery reflect on how she was being pressured to change her name -- (20:46) 'This Time I Almost Made it' is discussed as an homage to Barbara Mandrell from Lynne that had been produced with some internal conflict -- (22:40) Lynne tells of her life growing up in Alabama and her father's military career -- (23:10) Lynne addresses living in Alabama and Texas -- (23:30) Lynne and Collie address Lynne's sister and Lynne's physical characteristics -- (23:51) Lynne tells of how she had always been a performer and Lynne recalls her first public performance at Shakey's Pizza Parlor in Mobile, Alabama -- (24:28) 'What About This Girl' is reflected on as an up-tempo song created to address the popularity of the album -- (25:13) 'Til You Were Gone' writers Reid and Bourke are reflected on as positives -- (25:55) Collie brings up how Reid is a former football player and how Bourke was head of promotions for Mercury Records -- (26:28) 'I Love You So Much It Hurts' is reflected on by Collie reminiscing on the first time he played it in 1947; additionally, Lynne and Montgomery address the slump the album was in when they decided to record 'I Love You So Much It Hurts' -- (28:23) Montgomery tells of when Lynne performed 'I Love You So Much It Hurts' on Nashville now and the complement she received from Bill Monroe -- (29:33) 'That's Where It Hurts' is reflected on by Lynne and Montgomery as a song that Montgomery hates because he believes its another version of 'I've Been Everywhere' -- (30:55) Collie and Lynne discuss Lynne's traveling band, Lynne opening for Randy Travis, and Lynne's bus -- (31:47) Montgomery and Lynne address working with Travis as a great opportunity, and Montgomery and Lynne reflect on their initial fears of performing before Travis -- (33:48) Collie addresses the number of new tracks on the Sunrise album -- (34:29) Lynne reflects on her classical inspirations behind 'I'm Confessin'' -- (35:35) 'Your Love Stays with Me' is discussed by Lynne, Collie, and Montgomery as a gospel song that Lynne had difficulties recording -- (36:35) Collie, Lynne, and Montgomery address how Lynne's album Sunrise was named as such without there being a track names 'Sunrise' on the album -- (37:55) Collie has Lynne reflect on who Lynne believes she is as a writer -- (38:53) Lynne says her closing thought
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Lynne, Shelby; Montgomery, Bob, 1919-1998; Collie, Biff;
